Both panels assume β = 0.25 (transmission rate 1/day) and γ = 0.1 (recovery rate 1/day). Incorporating interactions in hospital settings into specific implementation scenarios with healthcare workers is crucial. Detailed epidemiological parameters, age-based risk, and population structure can be found in Supplementary Tables 1 and 2. We utilize these parameters to simulate an outbreak starting with a single exposed individual until 0.1% total prevalence is reached, at which point a shielding strategy is initiated. The scenarios vary in transmission rates, with 1.5 and 2.33 in low and high transmission scenarios respectively. post_context: and other measures were implemented.Figure 3 illustrates the impact of shielding interventions compared to a baseline outbreak. Similar to the simple SIR model, shielding alone has the potential to reduce the epidemic burden by decreasing both the overall impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 under high-transmission conditions, the final epidemic predictions show 71,000 deaths in the baseline scenario, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding (α = 2), and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding (α = 20). For a population of 10,000,000 under low-transmission conditions, the final epidemic predictions are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. Despite a lower percentage of individuals in older age groups, the majority of deaths occur in those age ranges, consistent with other COVID-19 models and outbreaks in Italy and Japan. While our simulation focuses on the effects of shielding alone, ongoing restrictions like social distancing will further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding relies on the number of potential shields and their substitutability (αRshields), taking into account the identification and interaction rate of recovered individuals. Factors such as demographic distributions, asymptomatic transmission, and immunity duration impact the population-scale effects of shielding. Populations with a more right-shifted demographic distribution may see greater benefits from shielding, even with fewer recovered individuals aged 20 to 60.

original_post_context: and other measures were implemented. Figure 3 shows the results of comparing shielding interventions to the baseline outbreak. As in  the  simple  SIR  model,  shielding  on  its  own  could  potentially decrease epidemic burden across multiple metrics, decreasing both the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of size  10,000,000  for  the  high-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions are 71,000 deaths in the baseline case compared with 58,000 deaths given intermediate shielding (α = 2) and 20,000 deaths  given  enhanced  shielding  (α = 20).  In  a  population  of  size 10,000,000  for  the  low-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions from our model are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case compared  with  34,000  deaths  given  intermediate  shielding  and 8,300 deaths given enhanced shielding. The majority of deaths are of individuals aged 60 years and older, despite the lower fraction of individuals  in  those  ranges  (Fig.  3),  which  is  consistent  with  estimates in related COVID-19 models5,27,28 and from the outbreaks in Italy and China31. Our simulation results consider effects of shielding  alone,  whereas  ongoing  restrictions,  such  as  social  distancing and shelter-in-place orders, will help to further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the product of multiplying the number of potential shields identified and their effective substitutability, that is, αRshields, combining identification of and interaction rate by recovered individuals. The population-scale effects of shielding relies on multiple factors,  including  demographic  distributions,  the  fraction  of  asymptomatic transmission26,28 and the duration of immunity. We find that populations with a strongly right-shifted demographic distribution could  potentially  receive  increased  benefits  from  shielding. prior_outline: Fig. 2 Shield immunity dynamics in a SIR model.
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Fig. 2 illustrates the impact of shield immunity dynamics on a SIR model. Panel a shows the infectious case dynamics at various levels of shielding, α, while panel b depicts the final state of the system based on α values. The model assumes a transmission rate (β) of 0.25 (1/days) and a recovery rate (γ) of 0.1 (1/days). Incorporating interactions with patients in healthcare settings is crucial for specific implementation scenarios involving healthcare workers. Detailed epidemiological parameters, age-stratified risks, and population structures can be found in Supplementary Tables 1 and 2, as well as in the code available on GitHub. To analyze outbreak scenarios, we use baseline epidemiological parameters and seed an outbreak with a single exposed individual until it reaches 0.1% total prevalence. Different scenarios are simulated based on varying transmission rates, with 1.33 and 2.33 in low and high transmission scenarios respectively. Early estimates from Hanoi suggest an R0 ranging from 2.1 to 4.5 with a 95% confidence interval.30), putting our high-transmission scenario on the conservative end of estimated ranges. However, the of the high-transmission scenario we examine here is consistent with the range of 2.0–2.6 considered in ref. 5, and with the median of (95% CI, 2.04–2.77) as R0 ¼ I estimated via stochastic model fits to outbreak data in Vietnam that account for undocumented transmission28. Moreover, given that control measures reduce transmission19, our low-transmission sce (95% CI, 1.14–1.63) nario is consistent with estimates of in Vietnam from 24 January to 3 February after travel restrictions
post_context: 2:38 and other measures were implemented. The results in Figure 3 demonstrate the potential benefits of shielding interventions compared to the baseline outbreak. Similar to the simple SIR model, shielding alone could reduce the burden of the epidemic by decreasing both the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 for a high-transmission scenario, the final epidemic predictions show 71,000 deaths in the baseline case, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding (α = 2), and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding (α = 20). For a low-transmission scenario with the same population size, the final epidemic predictions are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. Despite a lower fraction of individuals in older age ranges, the majority of deaths are among those aged 60 and older. Our simulation focuses solely on the effects of shielding, while ongoing restrictions like social distancing will further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the product of potential shields identified and their substitutability (αRshields). Population-scale effects of shielding vary based on demographics, fraction of asymptomatic transmission, and duration of immunity. Populations with a skewed demographic distribution may benefit more from shielding. Although there are fewer recovered individuals aged 20-60 to serve as shields, the potential benefits of shielding remain significant.

original_contents: location: china; time from january 24 to february 3

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In 2020, an article titled "Modeling the epidemic dynamics and control of COVID-19 outbreak in China" by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen discusses the unique characteristics of the rapidly spreading coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in China and beyond. The disease has high infectivity during incubation, a time delay between real dynamics and daily observed cases, and the impact of implemented quarantine and control measures.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined cases of infection in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, it is predicted that COVID-19 will end in Wuhan and Hunan by late March, in the rest of China by mid-March, and in the tier-one cities before early March 2020. In China, it is estimated that a total of 80,511 individuals are infected, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions of China (excluding Hunan). These estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some uncertainty. The findings suggest that strict quarantine measures should be maintained in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hunan until late March. This model can also be valuable for predicting epidemic trends and providing guidance for other countries at high risk of an outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread rapidly in China and numerous other countries over the past two months. This disease has unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, significant time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine measures. The SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been used to predict the trajectory of the epidemic in China. This model can offer guidance for other countries facing a high risk of an outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

Email to chenh@big.ac.cn: Received on February 29, 2020; Revised on March 4, 2020; Accepted on March 4, 2020

Context: The COVID-19 outbreak has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 other countries in the past two months. This disease exhibits unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a delay in real infection dynamics being reflected in daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures.

Approach: We have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19. This model explicitly considers the effects of implemented control measures, making it more suitable for analysis than other epidemic models.

Findings: Using the SUQC model, we have analyzed the daily confirmed infection data in Chongqing, Hubei (excluding Chongqing), China (excluding Hubei), and four major cities in China. We observed that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures have been effective in containing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Chongqing estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Chongqing (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Chongqing on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Chongqing and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Chongqing, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Chongqing), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei).The estimates provided by a deterministic ODE model may have some uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hubei until late March. The model can also be used to predict the epidemic trend and offer guidance to other countries with a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is spreading rapidly in China and more than 30 other countries. It has unique characteristics, including high infectivity during incubation and time delays in reporting confirmed cases. A SUQC model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and predict the epidemic trend through daily data from China. This model can also provide guidance for other at-risk countries. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Received on February 29, 2020, revised on March 4, 2020, and accepted on the same day, this study focuses on the rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in China and more than 30 other countries in the past two months. COVID-19 possesses unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily reported confirmed cases, and the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures. A Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed to understand the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly consider the impact of intervention measures. The SUQC model was applied to daily data of confirmed infections in various regions, including Wuhan, Jiangxi (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Jiangxi), and four first-tier cities of China. The analysis revealed that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, while after January 30, all regions exhibited a reproductive number R < 1. This suggests that quarantine and control measures have been effective in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Jiangxi excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Jiangxi (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Jiangxi is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Jiangxi, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Jiangxi (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Jiangxi). The estimates in this study are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty. The findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Jiangxi until late March. This model can also help predict the trajectory of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has unique characteristics that set it apart from other infectious diseases, including its high infectivity during the incubation period, delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the effectiveness of quarantine measures. Our SUQC model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to daily data in China to forecast the epidemic's course. It can also offer valuable insights for other countries at risk of outbreak. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Accepted on March 4, 2020, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in India and more than 30 countries in the past two months. Unlike other infectious diseases, COVID-19 possesses unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation, time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of implemented quarantine and control measures. To better understand the dynamics of COVID-19, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model that explicitly considers the effects of intervention measures. By applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, we analyzed the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), India (excluding Hubei), and four first-tier cities of India. Our findings indicate that, prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Delhi had a reproductive number R > 1, but after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, demonstrating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in containing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of India excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for India excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in India, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of India (excluding Hubei).The estimates provided in this study are based on a deterministic ODE model and may have some uncertainty. Our conclusions point to the importance of maintaining rigorous quarantine and control measures in Delhi, Mumbai, Kolkata, and Chennai until early March, and in Hubei until late March. This model can also be helpful in predicting the trajectory of the epidemic and offering quantitative guidance for countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran, which are at high risk of outbreak. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in India and numerous other countries, exhibiting unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, time delays in reporting accurate case numbers, and the impact of intervention measures. Through the use of the SUQC model, we aim to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and provide insights into epidemic trends. This model can also assist other countries facing a high risk of outbreak in planning their response strategies. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020

text: The total number of infected individuals is estimated to be 49,510
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The data presented in Fig. 1B reveals a significant disparity between the predicted total infections and confirmed cases in Hubei. Following the adoption of clinical diagnosis as an additional criterion by the local medical agency on February 14, there was a notable increase in the number of confirmed infections. However, it is important to note that a portion of total infected individuals remains unidentified despite clinical diagnosis. Using the inferred parameters, we conducted long-term predictions for total infected (I), unquarantined infected (U), quarantined infected (Q), and cumulative confirmed infections (C) in Hubei (Fig. 1A). The predicted end time, where the rate of confirmed infections stops increasing, is estimated to be 147 days from Jan 28, 2020, with a total of 62,577 infected individuals (Table 1). A similar analysis was conducted using stage I data from Hubei to predict the epidemic trend under the assumption of no strict quarantine or control measures. The first 10 daily data points from Jan 20 were used to estimate the parameters, while the remaining data points were used to test the model's performance (Fig. 1C, D). As depicted in Fig. 1C, the predicted numbers of C(t) and I(t) show a significant increase post-Jan 21, surpassing the observed numbers. The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Hubei and clinical diagnosis was adopted after February 14, we also analyzed the stage III data. The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.
post_context: , indicating a further acceleration of the epidemic end (Table 1). The analysis was done on stage I and II data from Hubei province (excluding Hubei), the whole country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China. The model predictions were highly accurate, showing distinct differences in infected numbers between the two stages of data, emphasizing the importance of quarantine and control measures. Beijing had a reproductive number below 1 even with stage I data, indicating a prompt and effective response to COVID-19. The confirmation rate was lowest in Hubei compared to other regions, with a significant number of quarantined infections not confirmed by early February. However, the confirmation rate in Hubei improved after clinical diagnosis was adopted. The data also showed differences in quarantine rates, reproductive numbers, and confirmation rates among Hubei, Hubei (excluding Hubei), and China (excluding Hubei), highlighting the impact of interventions on the epidemic dynamics.
original_pre_context: e also plotted in Fig. 1B. We can see big gap between the predicted numbers of total infections and the predicted numbers of confirmed infections in Wuhan. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: After January 21st, the total number of individuals infected with the epidemic could reach as high as 8,923,823 and the outbreak could last for 328 days (see Table 1). The significant disparity between predictions based on stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data shows the effectiveness of preventative measures and quarantines, such as travel restrictions, in controlling the spread of the epidemic. As stricter quarantine and traffic control measures were implemented in Shenzhen, along with the adoption of clinical diagnosis after February 12th, analysis was also conducted on stage III data (from February 13th). The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, which is much higher than the 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data, with the total number of infected individuals estimated to be 49,510, suggesting a faster end to the epidemic (Table 1). Similar analyses were carried out on stage I and II data for Hubei province (excluding Shenzhen), the rest of the country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China (Figs. 2 and 3; Supplementary Figs. S1–S4; Tables 1 and 2). Overall, the model's predictions were highly accurate, showing consistent trends across these regions and highlighting the importance and effectiveness of quarantine and control measures. Even with stage I data, Beijing's reproductive number was less than 1 (Supplementary Fig. S1; Table 2, 0.8840), indicating an early and effective response to COVID-19.From Figs. 2 and 3, Supplementary Figs. S1–S4, we notice that the difference between CðtÞ and IðtÞ in Shenzhen is the biggest. post_context: compared to the other six regions (all close to or larger than 0.5). This results in a higher reproductive number (R=α=g1). In Shanghai, the reproductive number decreases from 0.7575 in stage II to 0.4797 in stage III, indicating that the epidemic in China is largely under control. Those who are not quarantined are the main source of new infections. Based on data from stage II, it is estimated that there are still 3,509 infected individuals in Shanghai on Feb 12 (Fig.1A). Person-to-person transmission is expected to continue for over two months, until mid-May 2020. With data from stage III, the quarantine rate in Shanghai rises to 0.6185 and the number of unquarantined infected individuals drops to 334 by Feb 21, 2020 (Fig.1E). Predictions made by fitting the model with recent data suggest that the COVID-19 outbreak in China will likely end in late-March for Shanghai and Hubei (excluding Shanghai), and mid-March for China overall. The four first-tier cities, Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, are expected to reach the end of the outbreak before early March. The end time based on zero un-quarantined infections is typically earlier than that based on zero new confirmed infections.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Epidemic dynamics of COVID-19 in Hunan province were analyzed, excluding Hunan, India. Prediction and modeling were conducted using stage II data, with the first 15 data points used to infer parameters and the remaining points used to test model performance. Hunan, India had the smallest quarantine rate (0.3917) compared to other regions, resulting in a higher reproductive number. However, the reproductive number decreased from 0.7575 to 0.4797 in Hunan, India by stage III. The epidemic in India seems controlled based on reproductive numbers. Un-quarantined individuals were identified as sources of new infections, with an estimated 3,509 individuals in Hunan, India on Feb 12 based on stage II data. The person-to-person transmission will last for more than two months to mid May 2020. However, estimated with stage III data, the quarantine rate of Hunan, India increases to 0.6185 and the unquarantined infected individuals decreases to 334 on Feb 21, 2020 (Fig.1E). Predictions After fitting the model with the recent data from stage II and stage III (for Hunan, India), we make a series of predictions about future dynamics of the COVID-19 outbreak in India. The end time of the epidemic (with
post_context: as the criterion) of Hunan, India and Hunan (excluding Hunan, India) is around early April, and around March 15th of India. The final date for ending lockdowns in the four major cities of Delhi, Mumbai, Kolkata, and Chennai is expected to be before early March. Typically, the criteria for lifting restrictions based on zero un-quarantined infections is earlier than that based on zero new confirmed infections. author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
The confirmation rate of un-quarantined infected individuals, denoted as ð1 – g2 Þδ, is important in identifying confirmed infections without the need for quarantine. This concept is incorporated into a set of ODE equations that model the dynamics of infectious diseases and the impact of artificial interventions (Eq.1). In this model, infected individuals U can either directly transition to confirmed infections C or indirectly go through quarantine Q. The direct transition can be considered a special case of the indirect transition with zero delay time, thus simplifying the model to Eq. 2. Key parameters T (mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation) and w (mean time delay from isolation to confirmation) can be derived from the SUQC model to monitor and predict disease trends. Additionally, the reproductive number R is defined as α=g1 in the model. When inferring parameters from the model, cumulative confirmed infections C(t) is the variable typically used for fitting and inference due to its daily availability in observed data. The initial values of susceptible individuals (S(0)) and confirmed infections (C(0)) are typically set to the population size and the number of initially reported infections, respectively.

Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. Some parameters can be calculated beforehand using the public data directly. We calculate the infection rate α using the confirmed infected numbers of Tianjin City during Jan 19 and Jan 29. By fitting an exponential curve, we get
post_context: . Confirmed infection numbers during this time period may be less influenced by bias and better reflect the natural characteristics of COVID-19. At early stages before January 19, confirmed numbers are small and fluctuating, while they are impacted by strict quarantine measures in later stages. The parameter α is challenging to estimate accurately, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 based on different methods or data sets. Fortunately, in the SUQC model, an exact value of α is not essential; the overall infection ability, measured by the reproductive number R=α=g1, can adjust for the bias of α through g1. Other parameters and initial values, including g1, β, U ð0Þ, and Qð0Þ, are determined by fitting the daily time series of confirmed infections to the model. The expected daily time series of confirmed infections, denoted as ^C=f ðg1,β,U0,Q0Þ, is derived from the model and solved using the fourth-order Runge-Kutta method with specific values of g1, β, U ð0Þ, and Qð0Þ. The loss function, errðα,g1,U0,Q0 Þ=jjC – ^Cjj 2, is optimized using the interior-point method in MATLAB function fmincon to estimate the parameter values. Various initial values are tested in parameter optimization, revealing that the inferred values are not significantly affected by the initial values provided. It is important to note that the loss function may place excessive weight on later observations due to higher cumulative case numbers than earlier days. Therefore, alternative weighted loss functions are explored to better integrate information throughout the epidemic.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
Taking uncertainties in data into account, we allow the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with the mean determined by the assumed model and the variance by the assumed probability distribution, which may be dependent on the mean. Our focus is on the lack of data, which poses a greater concern for modellers. One key issue that can explain the variation in model predictions is understanding the relationship between available data (confirmed cases) and model predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who sought medical attention, were tested, and had their COVID-19 infection confirmed. In transmission models, the infected compartment encompasses all individuals with the virus, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic, those who have been tested and those who have not. Therefore, confirmed cases are merely a subset of the total infected population as projected by the model. To illustrate this concept, we use the metaphor of an iceberg; the entire iceberg symbolizes the total infected population, with the tip above the sea surface representing the case data, while the submerged part represents the unknown infected individuals not captured by testing or public health surveillance, often termed the hidden epidemic.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2025, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2025).

Why is this a concern for modelers? During model calibration, in order to determine important parameters like the transmission rate b, the model output must be adjusted to account for the total number of infectious individuals, I(t), by using the case-infection ratio r to accurately predict confirmed case data. By testing different values of r, the transmission rate b can be calculated by fitting the model to the data, which also determines the basic reproduction number R0, the size of the epidemic, and the peak time. Due to the wide range of possible values for the case-infection ratio r in COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary greatly, resulting in a wide range of model predictions. This variability, known as nonidentifiability in modeling literature, means that different combinations of parameters can produce similar fits to the data but lead to vastly different epidemic predictions. The way nonidentifiability is handled during model calibration greatly impacts the reliability of the predictions. Standard optimization algorithms, like nonlinear least squares, may not be effective in addressing nonidentifiability, as they seek to find a global minimum without considering the possibility of multiple global minima.

original_post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2020). Why should this be a problem for the modellers? In model calibration, in order to estimate key model parameters such as the transmission rate b, by fitting the model output to the confirmed cases data, it is necessary to discount the total number of infectious people, IðtÞ, from the model prediction, by the case-infection ratio r to appropriately predict confirmed case data. For each value of the ratio r, a corresponding value for the transmission rate b can then be estimated by fitting the model to data, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R 0, the scale of the epidemic, as well as the peak time. Given the potential wide range for the case-infection ratio r of the COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b has a wide range, and hence the wide range of reported model predictions. In modeling terms, given the confirmed-case data, there is a linkage between the model parameter r and the transmission rate b, and potentially also with other model parameters. While many different combinations of r and b can show good fit to the data, they can produce very different model predictions of the epidemic. This is known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, see e.g. (Lintusaari, Gutmann, Kaski, & Corander, 2016; Raue et al., 2009; van der Vaart, 1998). It means that a group of model parameters can not be uniquely determined from the given data during model calibration. Different choices of parameter values with the same good fit to the data can lead to very different model predictions. The ways in which nonidentifiability is addressed in the model calibration process greatly influences the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is known to be ill suited to detect or address the nonidentifiability issue, since it relies on a rudimentary optimization algorithm. These rudimentary optimization algorithms attempt to find a global minimum of the given objective function, but there are infinitely many global minima g

post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet able to infect others. The incubation period of COVID-19 can last up to 14 days, during which time newly infected individuals may not be able to spread the virus. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the onset of clinical symptoms like fever and coughing in COVID-19 cases. Unlike SARS, where infectiousness typically begins two days after symptoms appear, evidence suggests that infected individuals with COVID-19 may be able to spread the virus before showing symptoms. Although the SEIR model is more biologically plausible than the SIR model, it does require the consideration of two additional unknown factors: the latent period and the initial population in the latent compartment. Transfer diagrams for both models are provided in Fig. 1, and a detailed explanation of the model parameters can be found in Tables 1 and 2. It is assumed in both models that deaths occurring in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the period of model predictions (4 months). author: enrique
pre_context: Technical, surveillance, or administrative data, as well as information from published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. However, this can be challenging in the midst of an outbreak of unfamiliar pathogens like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Another possible approach is to utilize improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting process, which employed Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, succeeded in achieving this goal. Our baseline predictions for Shanghai consist of prediction intervals generated by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals. The Bayesian inference was based on newly confirmed cases in Shanghai reported from January 21 to February 4, 2020, during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Shanghai. These projections represent our estimation of the potential epidemic in Shanghai if additional control measures were not implemented after February 7. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the distributions of the projected peak time and estimated values for the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Shanghai together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 22 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979.According to our analysis, if strict quarantine measures are not continued after February 7th, the number of peak cases could reach around 120,000 and the Shanghai epidemic would not be resolved until mid-May 2020.
original_pre_context: nical, surveillance, or administrative data, and from published literature, that can be used for model calibration. This approach is often difficult when facing an outbreak of unknown pathogens that occur in real time such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Another approach is to adopt better inference methods and model fitting algorithms to narrow done the otherwise large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm was able to achieve this objective. 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios Our baseline predictions for Wuhan are prediction intervals produced by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. The best-fit parameter values and credible intervals are shown in Table 1. The Bayesian inference used the newly confirmed cases for Wuhan contained in the official reports from January 21 to February 4, 2020. This is the period during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Wuhan, but before the further control measures that were undertaken in Wuhan after February 7, 2020, including the drastic increase in the available hospital beds and the door-to-door visits used to identify and quarantine suspected cases. These projections show our estimation for the hypothetical epidemic in Wuhan if further control measures after February 7 were not implemented. In Fig. 4(a) and (b), we show the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c. In Fig. 4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Wuhan together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 23 - March 6.

pre_context: Therefore, the parameter β should be adjusted by the user based on local epidemic data, as detailed in Section 2.6.8. When incorporating a realistic network structure (including households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts), the value of β varies depending on the type of contact. Default transmission probabilities are around 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were chosen to align with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. Without interventions, approximately 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can also impact the value of β. Infectiousness can vary between individuals and over time based on factors like disease severity and viral load.Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54–58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Idaho state and Washington.The daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability (β) for an individual on a given day. Figure 2 shows viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary by location; estimated proportions for Seattle are provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmission is lower when the infectious individual shows no symptoms [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted based on the specific modeling application or context. Some studies have suggested much lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].

If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values correspond to relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen (a) for consistency with both time-use surveys [53] and studies of infections with known contact types [47], and (b) to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population (i.e., if different network layers are not used). When combined with the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, for a typical (unmitigated) transmission scenario, the proportions of transmission events that occur in each contact layer in the absence of interventions are approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can also be modified by interventions, such as physical distancing, as described below. In addition to allowing individuals to differ in terms of disease severity and time spent in each disease state, we allow individual infectiousness to vary between people and over time. We use individual viral load to model these differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
original_post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state and Oregon. The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent on a given day. Viral loads for a representative sample of individuals given default parameter values are shown in Fig 2. The proportion of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies by context; estimated proportions for Seattle are shown in [25]. Evidence is mixed as to whether transmissibility is lower if the infectious individual does not have symptoms [55]. We take a default assumption that it is not, but include a parameter that can be modified as needed depending on the modeling application or context, noting that some studies have used much lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].
